page.title: 08RYE HILL COMMON
page.content: Before the Second World War,a large part of Rye Hill was Common Land.Much of the nation's food was imported, mostly by sea.During the War,German submarines sank many of the ships carrying food to Britain.With food in short supply,the Government paid Â£2 to farmers for every acre(0.4 hectare) farmed.Much grass land was planted with corn,and Common Land (where local people could graze animals freely) was also ploughed,along with waste land and even playing fields. After the War the Government did not return the lnd but posted notices to say it was for sale:Dorringtons Farm bought most of the Rye Hill area.Only a narrow belt on either side of the Rye Hill road remains common,and a worker at Rivetts tethers 3 or 4 heifers on it each day.
